title: Will Recep Tayyip Erdoğan cease to be president of Turkey before 15 July 2021?
preds: Seeing this question for the first time with only 9 days left on the counter- it seems extremely unlikely Erdogan would relinquish power, and no easily accessible information indicates indicates any health problems, mass protest movements or armed opposition resulting from said scandals, etc. Mass arrests in response to the failed coup of 2016 appear to have diminished the military's capacity to interfere in politics.

Nothing on the horizon to indicate a need to change my forecast. @sevedb Hello Severina, I'd certainly agree with all your comments (https://bit.ly/36er8E1), viz; there's certainly room for criticism of Erdogan's management of the economy, Covid-19, financial markets and his most recent canal plan. An he's certainly not new to the game of Turkish politics and the use of 'coups' and strong arm tactics. That said, unless there is some 'inside' information that's not yet been leaked, he looks fairly well entrenched and I've not seen anything about his health being questionable. Thus, it seems a rogue assassin is the only risk with this question.
Would be great to be wrong here, but probability is vanishing.
Not going anywhere.  Time running out on this question.
Half a percent for a chance of sudden death. Happy to be wrong on this one.
Moving to 0, as probability of death in time remaining (1M) is now <0.5%
There is only a few weeks and he looks alright

He has survived a coup before, and has since cemented his power by cracking down on press freedom and stacking institutions with loyal figures. Highly unlikely he will be forced out any time soon.

Do not see anything serious that threatens his position and his has a strong grip on power.

"SofaGate"
Erdogans numbness towards international allies is just appaling, and indicates a far reaching overestimation of his own strength. Financial markets are nervous, and speculative forces will have a heyday (and pay day). He will not look very potent in the end.

The Turkish government last month approved President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s plans to build a shipping canal in Istanbul similar to the Panama or Suez canals as an alternative to Turkey’s internationally used straits connecting Asia to Europe. More than 120 retired Turkish ambassadors released a statement on Friday warning the project could put the Montreux Convention in jeopardy and negatively affect Turkey’s “absolute sovereignty” over the waterways. Following that up, an open letter was signed by 104 retired admirals and published overnight on Saturday, causing an uproar among government officials who said it harkened back to coup times of Turkey’s past.
==============================
COMMENTS: Something is surely happening in Turkey. Besides the above points, there may be also criticism about the handling of COVID, and Turkey posted a concerning 14.97% annual rise in consumer prices in January. Surely there is lots of room for criticism about Erdogan's performance.
However, mid-July is still too close date for him to be taken off somehow. 
It isn't the first time that Erdogan takes advantage of real or not-so-real coups, he is not new to the game!

First, there's around a %1.8 base mortality rate per year for someone of Erdogan's age, and that means around a %1.12 chance of death until 15th July 2021. I'm rounding this down to %1. There are four successful attempts by the military to overthrow a Turkish government since 1950: 1960 and 1980 were direct coups, while in 1971 and 1997 a government was forced from power by softer military interference. Two coup attempts in the 1960s and one in 2016 failed, while in 2007 a military interference attempt through soft power during a constitutional crisis was unsuccessful. Consequently we may estimate that since the institution of free elections in Turkey in 1950, there has been a %11.4 chance that some kind of military interference in politics takes place every year, and out of these half of them result in the incumbent government losing power. Adjusting for the 7 and a half months remaining, this gives a %3.6 base chance that Erdogan is removed from office through military interference until 15th July 2021. Because of the measures taken to address precisely this possibility after 2016, I'm cutting this down to %2. (It's worth keeping in mind that such measures didn't save the Menderes government in the 1950s from a military overthrow in 1960, so I don't want to overdo the correction.) Finally, there's the possibility that an early election will be called before 15th July 2021 and that Erdogan will lose this election. Turkey has had 9 early elections since 1950, and 2 of these has resulted in the government who called for the elections losing power. This gives a base rate of 2/70 = %2.8 per year for this event, so adjusting by the amount of time remaining gives a base rate of %1.75.  I adjust this base rate down to %1 given the recent pronouncements of the subject of an early election by the president, which make an early election comparatively more unlikely but not impossible. Adding all of these together gives a %4 chance that Erdogan ceases to be president before 15th July 2021.

Reading through my back-log of economists since summer and TUrkey's interventions in Syria and Iraq, Erdogan is really making it hard to think of ways for him to leave the presidency. A look at the data: (https://sites.psu.edu/dictators/) If we take as a starting point the failed coup in 15/7/2016 for when turkey became ruled by an autocrat, this dataset can help us estimate how long these regimes typically last. OUt of the 280 regimes (some without end date)in the dataset 77 ended within 5 years, 28%. 1) 33 out of these 77 ended with a military coup. I'm no expert but i'm inclined to think that after the purge post-2016 this is a rather unlikely path. on the other end, erdogan popularity is now seemingly increasingly reliant on military might displayed abroad, seemingly strengthening the position of military leaders. 
>> maybe this is a path but highly unlikely 2) 13/77 end with the incumbent not running for relection. unless the 2023 pres elections are moved forward this is irrelevant for this question. 
>> i guess this path is closer related to erdogan personal wellbeing than to anything else really 3) another 11/77 end with popular uprising 
(to be furhter investigated here: https://www.fastcompany.com/90580697/tech-investor-on-e-commerce-trends-even-amazon-is-becoming-a-storyteller) the other options are related to gradual change or extreme events like a foreign invasion, civil war or state faillure.
I think in the current time window this are also highly unlikely. That leads me to substantially reduce the baserate (28%), but a factor 10 seems to extreme.
The result of this analysis thus makes me somewhat more confident to Erdogan go. ps: I haven't included other variables (unemployment rate, fx reserves, covid, war,...) so that could be improved upon.

Incapacitation, death or a coup are the other options. Given the result of the last coup it would take a brave (or foolish) person to organise, so overall a low probability event.

My reasoning is identical to @mwackers except I attach 0% probability to the treat from Biden causing Erdogan to cease to be in power. Hence no need for me to type out my own essentially copy and past reasoning.  The only path to removal of Erdogan seems to be a coup, and given the last failed coup, Erdogan has already made that path significantly more difficult. But in that region, a coup cannot be ruled out completely.  That being said, a small amount of research revealed this, from the highly reliable euobserver news website.
https://euobserver.com/foreign/144366
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/EUobserver (if it's good enough for EU officials to take seriously, it's good enough for me) The source of this article seems to be an EU intelligence report.
"
But the IntCen report on the coup, dated 24 August 2016, and seen by this website, said it was "unlikely that Gulen had the abilities and the capacities to take such steps", even if some individual Gulenists were involved in the attempted overthrow.
According to available information, a far-reaching purge of the GM's [Gulen movement's] followers in the armed forces and the gendarmerie was planned for early August 2016 based on lists produced by the MIT [Turkish intelligence]. Some arrests were already planned for 16 July, the day after the coup attempt", the EU report added.
The coup was just the catalyst for the crackdown prepared in advance," the IntCen report said."
"
Apparently, the coup was to some extent government controlled and latest intelligence assessments are that Erdogan permitted it to happen to justify has later crushing of all potentially independent institutions in Turkey. So even that coup probably wasn't a full "normal" coup. That being said, it is still possible Turkey had organised the crackdown and the coup itself simply caused Erdogan to start the crackdown early and immediately. So a genuine coup cannot be ruled out.  I would have attached 5% probability to a coup, but given the EUObserver article, that gets reduced to 2.5%. The last remaining path to Erdogan no longer being in power is, once again, his death. 
Erdogan is 66 years old. The deadline is 1 3/4 years. Actuarial tables show his probability of death in 1 year is 1.7% and the probability of death in the subsequent year is 1.8%, which we multiply by 3/4 giving 1.35%. Summing the two makes 3%.  Total: 2.5% + 3% = 5.5%. I round towards uncertainty to account for the chance I have missed something.

Politically Erdogan seems safe. As of July 2020 opinion poll, Erdogan received 52% positive view from those polled. This is up from a low of 44% in April.  Next presidential election is not scheduled until 2023 and Erogan leads in opinion polls. Erdogan polls between 39%-50%. Potential challengers do not exceed 35%. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2023_Turkish_general_election Erdogan has faced and weathered corruption in the past, most notably in 2013-2015 when there were calls for his resignation.
https://foreignpolicy.com/2015/01/06/why-turkeys-mother-of-all-corruption-scandals-refuses-to-go-away/ Turkey has imposed restriction on social media and the press, which could strengthen Erdogan's hold on power.
"Turkey on Thursday entered a new era of tight social media restrictions that threaten to erase the local presence of Facebook and Twitter should they fail to take down contentious posts.
The legislation was rammed through parliament by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's ruling AKP party and follows the government's crackdown on opposition newspapers and television channels."
https://japantoday.com/category/world/turkey-begins-life-under-strict-social-media-rules International Standing- The US election could have implications for Erdogan's future or relations with the US and EU. Turkey seems to be able to use if close relationship with President Trump as a means to ignore EU criticism. Erdogan has also been able to use his relationship with Putin to strengthen regional policy issues.
But leveraging these relationship also depend on Trump winning the 2020 Presidential Election. Diminished relationship with the US stemming from a Biden win, or a scandal from congressional investigations could be threats to Erdogan's hold on power.

There are no viable options for Turkish presidency and Erdogan has made sure of that. While an unpleasant fellow, he has working relationships with all substantial middle eastern countries, and serves as a moderating factor (if you can believe that!). His objectives are similar to those of S Arabia and Iran, who are the two big kids duking it out in the region, and can play match-maker. He is highly pragmatic despite his obvious flaws and has the flexibility to survive. While an assassination is possible, these are generally quite rare globally. He is a "both ends against the middle" guy. Not going anywhere soon.

Turkey is deeply involved in this fight and backing Azerbaijan. (The Turkish government also hates the Armenians, due to their historic genocide claims against Turkey. See, I told you this was going to get complicated.) The trouble is Armenia is a member of the Russian-led Collective Security Treat Organisation (CSTO) – a sort of Nato for Eastern Europe – while Turkey is an actual member of Nato. There is a scenario where Azerbaijan’s attack on Armenia triggers the CSTO and Russian forces come to its aid and find themselves fighting Turkish forces which triggers Nato’s article V clause. It’s not that likely, but the possibility only highlights how fraught this military clash is.

The next election is not until 2023 (5 year offices) although there are constant discussions in Turkey of an early election in 2021.  Terms for the President and all 600 Parliament members are for five years and while early elections have occurred before, they were months early, not years.  According to some political scientists in Turkey, an early election wouldn't happen until August or September '21, but the chances of an early election that soon amidst the pandemic and economic, military, religious and political issues seems very slim.  An early election would allow Erdogan to employ a constitutional loop hole that allows him to go beyond the two-term limit with the dissolving of Parliament and would catch the two new opposition parties unprepared and un-consolidated.  While the motivation to do this is high, Erdogan needs to ensure that his dwindling support in the nation is enough for an early win.

The constitutional referendum has strengthened his hold and the failed coup has also strengthened his hold over the country however the  economic crisis has lost him quite a lot of popularity and the ruling party losing local elections Ankara and Istanbul after 15 years has also to be taken into account(said to be the reason for his decline in popularity).

Erdogan, although not a dictator but is billed a strongman and bully. The opposition to him at home appears to ineffectual at national level. Erdogan has the confidence to straddle a variety of fences. Turkey is a member of NATO and yet the country is purchasing Russian missile systems; he appears to be on good terms with Putin as an ally in both Libya and Syria; he has determined Turkey to be the defender of the Muslim faith and has defended Palestinian rights against the recent Arab agreements to recognise Israel. He is friendly with Trump. 
Erdogan cannot be compared to previous leaders of modern Turkey and their length of tenure as he used a popular referendum to shift a parliamentary system to an an executive presidency, abolishing the position of Prime minister, diminishing the power of parliament and gaining the ability to rule by decree and appoint ministers and judges and control the budgets of the military and police.
Rather than hedging his bets, he appears to confident in expanding the influence of his country and he has achieved internally and is probably in position for the long term.

https://www.npr.org/2020/05/25/861909600/turkish-president-may-call-elections-2-years-prior-the-end-of-his-term-- Great article here from NPR.  To be clear, Erdogan has only been president since 2014... and the last two presidents served about 7 years, respectively.  But Erdogan started as PM from 2003-14, became President, and in the reforms of 2017, should run for his second term in 2023.  The article linked above suggests that Erdogan might try to catch opposition flat footed by a vote in 2021.   So, 7 years is pretty standard for Presidents of Turkey at least after the turn of the century.  Inside view: Erdogan will not press for 2021 elections unless he is assured of a win.  Consequently, we should anticipate that he remains president through July 2021.

Erdogan is a classic strongman dictator, who has jailed or killed all known opposition. Deposing dictators can happen but is extremely difficult from within. He has played US and Russia very well, and know that both need him in power. Further limiting the odds of any outside help in ousting him.

Another round of seems very unlikely. Points for a potential step down would include a new round of hostility popping up in the Middle East, an uprising within Turkey, or unexpected health reasons. Generally though, he doesn't have to seek reelection until 2023, world leaders tend to not step down if they don't have to (that base rate has to be basically 0 for an established leader, except in the case of poor health - Shinzo Abe for example). Erdogan hasn't had a super clear track record in the help department, which brings this up to at least a non-zero chance.
it's only 1% for the time frame, to summarize a position I've stated before, we are in a period of humanity where politicians and leaders do not step down, under any circumstances
The Sultanchik is certainly no Spring Turkey, but unless a certain bat virus gets him, looks like he'll be keeping his Corona.

I’m likely high at 1%. That’s simply in case of accidental death. He’s not going anywhere for political reasons. The Sultan is relatively young (66) and in decent shape. There have been some health scares - which I can’t vouch for given lack of transparency.

Erdogan seem to have strengthened his hold on power. Election isn't until 2023. I don't see any street movements who could change things. I hope I'm wrong, but with the exception of a sudden death I have a hard time seeing Erdogan replaced.
There are about 10-1/2 months in this question. A lot can change in that time, but Turkey is one I just don't have the imagination to conceive of how.

Short of assassination Tayyip could be in power even longer than Putin.  With a very strong base of support and consolidation of the power points in Turkey, elimination of threat from the Generals,  he is as secure in his position.
The odds of any leader ceasing to be the leader (maybe Putin is the exception) has probably not been any higher than since WW2, Erdogan is no exception but not giving him necessarily higher odds.

The only thing that matters is the economics.  Inflation and lira value.  The lira is not a free floating currency, it is managed.  The pandemic has produced the dollars from tourism that turkey usually gets this stresses the economy. The government and the central bank have tried to keep rates low and push money into the markets and that resulted in a credit boom which makes people happy but can't last forever. Turkey always seems to be one months away from a currency crisis and yet the crisis never seems to happen. There always seems to be storm clouds on Horizon and it never rains. So  Erdogan is safe until impending economic collapse. He is to clever to commit and international relations sin that would remove him from office.  He uses the international stage to distract from the potential economic calamity that worries him.  It also serves to remind Europe and the USA that it is better to have turkey weekend and running around on its own.
